Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Photonic Materials Molecular Beam Epitaxy System

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: Through this grant we plan to assemble a multi-chamber semiconductor epitaxy system to enable the creation of high-quality optoelectronic materials and devices. This apparatus will consist of an automated molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) system with access to at least two epitaxy chambers. The entire system will be available for everyone in the research and business community. Also, a full time engineer will staff the system to grow samples for outside users.
Intellectual Merits: The systems chambers will have high band-gap III-V and Low band-gap III-V chambers along with the possibility for a Group IV (SiGeSn) and Oxide capability expansion. The MBE chambers will all be part of a Veeco Gen10A/20A MBE system, which is fully automated, making it easy for novice users to handle. A characterization tools from existing systems will be moved into the preparation chamber for this system. This multi-chamber system enables a significant number of experiments that would not be possible in separated systems due to the destructive influence exposure to atmosphere can cause. The mixture of components in this system will enable everything from the most fundamental materials research to the development of highly advances devices. This tool will be unique in the world and, better yet, it will be available to the general community.
Broader Impact: The multi-chamber epitaxy system will be available for general use. While the standard rates used will be equal to those charged in NSF funded NNIN centers, we also intend to donate up to 10% of the available machine time for use by disadvantaged and minority serving institutions at substantially reduced rates or even for free. Tufts dedication to public service backed by its strong financial solvency makes it an ideal location to house this equipment. Additionally, the concentration of high-tech start-up companies, colleges, and universities in the Boston-area enhance the ideality of its placement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through this award we purchased a multi-chamber Veeco GenXplor molecular beam epitaxy system.  This system is focused on the III-V material system combining aluminum, gallium, indium, and thallium with phosphorus, arsenic, antimony, and bismuth.  This combination of materials enables the creation of photonic materials with band gaps large enough to work with ultraviolet light and small enough to even create negative band gaps, i.e. semimetals.  New materials can lead to new devices and improve existing ones.  This multi-chamber system enables a significant number of experiments that would not be possible in separated systems due to the destructive influence exposure to atmosphere can cause.  The mixture of components in this system will enable everything from the most fundamental materials research to the development of highly advances devices.  Some of the possible applications include: ultra-efficient solar cells, infrared photodetectors, LED lighting, high-speed transistors, heterogeneous integration, and many more.  This tool is unique in the world and, better yet, it will be available to the general community.

The system forms the keystone of the new Tufts Epitaxial Core Facility, which is a user facility open to all for a fee.  This facility offers a unique capability to the community and will be used by both academics and local industry to prototype potential new products. With this system employed as a user facility the broader impacts of its acquisition are manifold.  Future operators of this instrument from a number of institutions and companies have already indicated their desire to begin using it.  Some of the signed up users already have epitaxial systems of their own, but recognize the advantages of this new system to perform experiments not possible with their equipment.  This will have a wide-ranging impact on student projects, theses, and dissertations and will help to train many of the next generation of scientists and engineers.   This grant has enhanced the opportunity for students to apply and expand upon the knowledge they have gained in the classroom and utilize it in a research setting. 

 

For the small start-up company, this epitaxial user facility can mean the difference between success and failure.  Many of the start-ups that have already signed up to be users of the system are focused on green technology, which might change the way we live and think about power in the future.  The establishment of this system at Tufts University will have a transformative impact on the local research community and the national one as a whole for decades to come.
